abstract.text: This paper examines the individual records of patients treated for COVID-19 during the early phase of the pandemic in Ontario. We trace out daily transitions of patients through medical care of different intensity and address the right truncation in the database. We also examine the sojourn times and reveal duration dependence in the treatments for COVID-19. The transition model is used to estimate and forecast the counts of patients treated for COVID-19 in Ontario, while adjusting for the right truncation and right censoring in the sample. This research is based on the Public Health Ontario (PHO) data set from May 7, 2020.

body_text.text: nombre de patients traités pour le COVID-19 en Ontario, tout en tenant compte de la troncatureà droite et de la censureà droite dans l'échantillon. Cette recherche est basée sur des données de Santé publique Ontario datant du 7 mai 2020.
JEL classification: C32, C59

A BASIC EPIDEMIOLOGICAL SIRD model distinguishes four individual states (see, e.g., Kermack and McKendrick 1927 , Vinnicky and White 2010 , Yan and Chowel 2019 , Toda 2020 . State S of susceptible comprises individuals who are healthy and not yet immunized. In state I of infected, the individuals are infected and not yet recovered. An infected individual can either recover (move to state R) or die (move to state D). This causal scheme, which can be summarized as

is a chain that involves two episodes. The first episode between states S and I concerns the propagation phase of the disease and the process of detection of infected individuals. The second episode concerns the disease monitoring that follows a diagnosed infection. In this paper, we are interested in the analysis of individual medical care histories. Therefore, we divide the state of infected into states of medical care of increasing intensity, which depend on the severity of symptoms. These additional states include hospitalization, intensive care unit (ICU), ventilation and intubation. Our analysis of COVID-19 infections in Ontario is based on daily records of 18,722 individuals who were diagnosed with COVID-19 over the period of 104 days between January 23 and May 5, 2020, and reported in the Public Health Ontario (PHO) database of combined records from integrated Public Health Information System (iPHIS) and Toronto Public Health Coronavirus Rapid Entry System (CORES).

The objective of our research is to introduce a modelling approach for the analysis of counts of patients under medical care that produces reasonably accurate results, given the complexity of problems encountered in the data. Some of those problems are related to the data collection method. These are, for example, the missing and misreported dates of medical treatments, the recovery dates being unavailable or unknown outcomes of medical care. Other problems are related to the statistical analysis of data with right censoring and truncation, which is amplified by the delay in data reporting of up to 10 last days of the sampling period.
The publicly available data on COVID-19 infections in Ontario are aggregated at various levels and communicated in the PHO reports (see, e.g., Public

Health Ontario 2020a, b), which contain the counts of confirmed and deceased individuals by age or region of Ontario. The Enhanced Epidemiological Summary (Public Health Ontario 2020a) shows additional counts of patients who are hospitalized and in the ICU. Below, we display similar series of counts computed from our sample until May 4, after a preliminary individual data adjustment for missing and misreported data (see online appendix B1). Figures 1 and 2 show the cumulated and daily counts of Diagnosed and Deceased individuals, respectively. These figures can be compared with figures 1 and 4 in Public Health Ontario (2020b, pp. 3 and 6) reporting the confirmed cases of infections and deaths over a longer sampling period to May 27. The patterns prior to May 5 revealed in figures 1 and 2 are Because of a reporting lag, the last few daily counts in figures 1 and 2 need to be considered with caution.

In figure 2 , the daily increments reveal hump-shaped patterns, which resemble the curves of standard epidemiological SIRD models. The dates of peaks are, approximately, April 15, 2020, for the diagnosed and deceased patients. There is also a seasonal (weekly) effect in reporting that creates a jagged pattern in figure 2.

The curves of daily counts display a non-stationary behaviour with a phase of growth followed by a decline. The aggregated data do not allow us to disentangle the possibly multiple sources of this non-stationarity, such as the nonstationary propagation of the pandemic with an exponential increase in the early phase, the effect of disease detection that depends on the reliability and availability of tests and the efficiency of treatment for COVID-19. The latter one can improve over time as a result of advancement of knowledge about the disease or worsen as a result of shortages of medical staff and equipment. Figure 3 shows the daily counts of patients under medical care and can be compared with figure 1 (ICU, hospitalization) in Public Health Ontario (2020a, p. 3), which is based on a shorter sampling period ending on April 22 (or with figure 2 in Public Health Ontario 2020c). We observe that the peak of the curve depends on the sampling period. The timing of that peak seems to be, approximately, April 1 in figure 1 of Public Health Ontario (2020a) and April 11 in figure 3. This difference is likely due to a truncation bias. This bias is discussed in section 2.3 and adjusted for by considering the state transitions instead of "crude" counts. Figure 4 presents changes in daily counts displayed in figure 3 . These patterns can be compared with figure 3 in Aguerragibiria et al. (2020) , which illustrates observations recorded over a period ending on April 22. The difference between the patterns displayed in the two figures seemingly confirms a misleading effect of truncation. Nevertheless, both figures reveal daily fluctuations due to the fact that the counts of individuals under medical care are determined by both the entry and exit effects.

Our approach to examining the individual records relies on a transition model, where each individual is represented by a "history" variable, i.e., a sequence of states (see, e.g., Gourieroux and Jasiak 2007, ch. 8) . It allows us to adjust for right censoring and attenuate the truncation bias. The state dynamics are defined through transition matrices, which are functions of the current and past environment.

An advantage of the transition model is that it allows for including time and individual dependent explanatory variables, such as the time already spent in the state, i.e., the duration dependence. The analysis of the transition model with duration dependence for Ontario leads to the following observations:

The longer an individual stays hospitalized, the lower the probability of moving to the ICU or of being intubated. The probabilities of recovering and of dying of COVID-19 increase with the length of medical treatment. The probability of death seems to increase with the time spent in all types of medical care, at rates depending on the intensity of care. The results concerning the probability to recover are affected by the lack of the date of recovery and need to be interpreted with caution.

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 describes the states of medical care and illustrates the individual histories of transitions between states. The truncation problem is also discussed. Section 3 presents the empirical data analysis and summary statistics computed under a simplifying assumption of homogeneous Markov chain. Then, the assumption of stationarity of the medical care process is discussed. Section 4 presents the transition model with duration dependence, where the probabilities of transition from each state depend on the time already spent in that state. The model is applied to the entire province of Ontario and also separately to the diagnosing health unit areas of Toronto and the rest of the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), revealing the heterogeneity effects. Section 5 concludes. Additional figures (A1 to A5) are given in the appendix. The data set and data processing, the summary statistics of sojourn times in each state and supplementary tables and figures are relegated to online appendices B1, B2 and B3, respectively.

This section introduces the states and the transitions and describes the discrete time dynamic transition model based on the individual histories. These examples of individual histories of patients underlie our approach and suggest the selection of states given below.
The data set allows us to distinguish nine latent states. The states are redefined for compatibility with the transition model and the availability of data.

State 0. Undiagnosed: From the beginning of the sampling period until the case reported date or a transition date to the next state. On "the case reported date" the individual is diagnosed as COVID-19 infected and enters a follow-up stage that includes self-isolation and/or states of medical treatment. State 1. D: Diagnosed: From the case reported date until the medical care, death or recovery. Because the population of Ontario was supposed to self-isolate during the sampling period, we include in state D individuals who are not currently hospitalized and not yet recovered: see below the definition of recovered. Therefore, we have D = isolation + selfisolation. The isolation can be prior to or after medical treatment, which are denoted by D 1 and D 2 , respectively. The records contain a limited amount of information on individual isolation. There are very few cases of isolation reported in the data set and their locations are unknown. State 2. ER: Emergency room State 3. H: Hospitalization due to COVID-19 (hospitalization for other reasons is disregarded) State 4. ICU: Intensive care unit State 5. V: Ventilation. To help adjust breathing, a machine is used to move air in and out of the patient lungs. Ventilators (also called respirators) are machines of different types, including computerized microprocessor controlled machines, as well as continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and non-invasive ventilators. This state of medical care is called ventilation. State 6. T: Intubation. The state Intubation refers to placing a tube in the patient's throat to help move air in and out of the lungs while protecting the airway, which is a long-term ventilator dependence with a tracheotomy cannula.

In many cases, the time spent in hospitalization, intensive care, intubation or on a ventilator overlap. Given that the states should be disjoint, we proceed as follows: we treat an individual as being intubated if this stage overlaps with others (because being intubated means that the individual is already in intensive care, under a ventilator and breathing through a tube). Similarly, if a patient is in intensive care and on a ventilator, we consider him or her to be using a ventilator. When a patient is in intensive care and under hospitalization, we consider him or her as in intensive care.

The states considered above are distinct. The states of medical care 3 to 6 are marked with a star in the scheme below showing how they are related to the counts of patients under each treatment given in the PHO report:
For ease of exposition, the non-starred symbols are used henceforth, assuming the reader is aware of the above distinction.

Accordingly, among the 18,722 individuals diagnosed in our data set, 2,047 individuals went through medical care for COVID-19 during the sampling period of 104 days. The total counts of individuals who at some point over the sampling period were in the distinct (starred) states of medical care given above, are: 138 in ER, 1,376 in H, 243 in ICU, 46 in V and 244 in T.

State 7. R: Recovered. This state is an important component of a SIRD model. However, for COVID-19, the notion of recovery is not clearly defined and the date of recovery is unknown. The database combines two sources mentioned earlier, which are the iPHIS and CORES that are seemingly not reporting the recovery in the same way. In the most recent PHO practice, the recovery date is determined conventionally as follows. According to the PHO documents, "the following cases are considered resolved" (but referred to as "recovered" in the daily Ontario provincial report for the media):

-Cases that are reported as "recovered" in iPHIS on the basis of the local public health unit assessment -Cases that are not hospitalized and are 14 days past their symptom onset date or specimen collection date -Cases that are currently hospitalized, have a case status of "closed," indicating that public health follow-up is complete and are 14 days past their symptoms There is a lack of coherency in this definition because several individuals reported "recovered" by the iPHIS may still have COVID-19 symptoms and the definition depends on the local health unit.
In our analysis, we have adopted a similar approach to setting conventionally the date of state R. For that reason, some results concerning the time to recover have to be considered with caution.
State 8. DE: Deceased. 1 Individuals who are not recovered or deceased can remain in their last state on May 5, causing a right-censoring problem.

Let us now consider the state of all individuals on May 5. On that day, the data set reports 13,218 individuals recovered and 1,429 deceased. Therefore, on May 5, there are 4,075 right-censored histories. Among those, 4,046 individuals are in state D, one is in state ER, 22 are hospitalized and six are intubated. Because of the lack of a clear definition of recovery, there are 4,046 individuals in state D who were diagnosed less than 14 days ago.

Concerning the right truncation of individual histories for individuals who are under medical care on May 5, 1,043 Ontarians are hospitalized on May 5 as reported by the "Global News" on that day. Among them, 223 are in the ICU and 166 are under ventilation (according to the PHO definition). At the same time, 3,504 critical care beds are available, including 2,811 beds equipped with ventilators (see Office of the Premier 2020). Therefore, the database suffers from a right-truncation problem because very few individuals are reported under medical care on May 5.

Because individuals undergoing treatment for COVID-19 may stay in hospital for as long as three weeks, the counts in figure 3 are reliable until days 80 to 85 (April 11 to April 16). In particular, the decrease in counts observed in figure 3 is misleading and due essentially to the truncation in the database.

In fact, the data available on May 5 show that the curves of counts need to be projected upward to obtain correct predictions for May 5 and the following days (see section 4.3). Similar biases may also arise in the analysis of crude sojourn times in each state (see, e.g., Lapidus et al. 2020 for the application to COVID-19 and Blanghaps et al. 2013 and Schweer and Wickelhaus 2015 for theoretical results).

body_text.text: The transitions of interest are conditional on diagnosis. The following conditional state transitions are assumed to occur:

The probabilistic model concerns the histories of diagnosed individuals over the set of states given above. The individuals are indexed by i, i = 1, . . ., n, where n is the total size of the sample. The model is applied to the individual histories starting from a common date t 0 equal to the first detection date of January 23, 2020.

Because the individuals are diagnosed at different dates, we introduce the state 0 of "undiagnosed" in order to align the individual histories on a common time axis. The histories can be characterized as either:

(a) by the dates of jumps from one state to another or, equivalently, by the ordered sequence of occupied states with given sojourn times in each state (this is how the examples of individual histories in section 2.1 are reported) or (b) by a qualitative time series with given occupied state indicators on each day. For example, the individual history "0001111111111111111112333 3334444411111111111111111111111117" represents an individual who is undiagnosed for three days (0s) of the sampling period, isolated (state D) for 18 days (1s) and who then enters the ER (2) and remains in hospital for six days (3s). Next, the patient is moved to the ICU for five days (4s), returns to state D (1s) and recovers (7).

These two representations are equivalent and their use depends on the purpose of study. The database relies on representation (a), which takes less space, while a dynamic model can be applied to either representation. Our estimation method is based on the qualitative time series representation (b) in order to easily accommodate the right censoring.

Let us denote by {Y i,t , t = t 0 , t 0 + 1, ..}, i = 1, . . ., n the individual histories since the common date t 0 . At the beginning of the history, the individual is still undetected and undiagnosed with Y i,t = 0, by convention. After diagnosis date S 0;i that depends on each individual, Y i,t is a qualitative variable with eight possible states described above. The main probabilistic assumption is the following.

Because we focus our analysis on the medical care history conditional on the diagnosis, only the conditional distribution of fY i;t , t ≥ S 0;i g given S 0;i , Y i;S 0;i is relevant. This conditional distribution is characterized by a sequence of transition matrices P i,t that provides the conditional distributions of Y i,t given S 0;i , Y i;tÀ1 , where Y i;tÀ1 contains all past observations up to and including time t − 1.
Assumption A1 allows for a variety of specifications for the sequence of transition matrices, some of which are examined in the empirical analysis in sections 3 and 4.
(i) Homogeneous Markov chain ASSUMPTION A2(a). P i,t = P, independent of i and t, i = 1, . . ., n, t > S 0;i . The elements of matrix P are denoted by p jk .
This assumption can be equivalently written under representation (i) in terms of dates of jumps and states following those jumps. This representation is denoted by
The successive sojourn times are denoted by D l,i = S l+1,i − S l,i ,. . . . Then, we obtain the following result (see, e.g., Cinlar 1969 , Cox 1970 ).
PROPOSITION 1. The homogeneous Markov chain assumption (i.e., assumption A2(a)) is satisfied if and only if:

(i) The series of distinct successive states is Markov with transition matrixP that contains the probabilities of each jump conditional on the previous state, equal top j;k ¼ p j;k =ð1 À p jj Þ, 8j, k, j ≠ k and

. . n, conditional on the series of Y l;i , l ¼ 1, 2, ::::, the sojourn times D l,i , l = 1, 2, . . ., are independent, such that the distribution of D l,i is a geometric distribution with parameter p jj , where j ¼Ỹ l;i .

Such an independence property of the sojourn times conditional on the occupied state characterizes a renewal process and facilitates simulations as well as the derivation of asymptotic properties of the estimators. The homogeneous Markov chain is the benchmark model that can be extended in various respects.
(ii) Time-dependent chain ASSUMPTION A2(b). P i,t = P t , independent of i and dependent on t.

This model allows us for taking into account the calendar time effects, such as the shortages of medical staff and hospital beds, the advancement of knowledge about the disease or the fact that individuals get diagnosed sooner, which helps them recover.
(iii) Chain with duration dependence ASSUMPTION A2(c). P i;t ¼ P tÀS l t ;i , where S l t ;i is the date of the most recent jump.

This transition depends on the time already spent in the current state. Under assumption A2(c) the process maintains some properties of a renewal process, although the sojourn time distributions are no longer geometric distributions andỸ l;i , l ¼ 1, . . ., n is no longer a Markov chain.
(iv) Chain with cohort effect

The transition depends essentially on the diagnosis time. If we consider a given cohort (or generation) of individuals P s 0 ¼ fi : S 0;i ¼ s 0 g composed of individuals diagnosed on the same date s 0 , we have P i;t ¼ P s 0 , for i ∈ P s 0 : Therefore, for each cohort, we have a homogeneous Markov chain, but the chain is no longer homogeneous if all cohorts are confounded because of some aggregation bias.

It is possible to consider more complex specifications by introducing jointly the time dependence, duration dependence, a cohort effect and/or also the effects of individual characteristics such as the gender, age, comorbidity, etc.

This section presents time independent summary statistics that can be easily computed by averaging individual histories over time and/or individuals. The statistics discussed in this section are transition frequencies and sample densities of sojourn times in a given state. These statistics are interpreted under the homogeneous Markov chain assumption. The time dependence is discussed at the end of this section. Table 1 presents the transition matrix P estimated from the entire sample. The matrix can be interpreted as follows. Regardless of individual characteristics, the probability that an individual who is currently hospitalized is admitted to the ICU is 0.468% and that he/she dies is 2.874%, regardless of how long the patient has stayed in hospital.

The first six lines of this transition matrix represent a "production process" of the medical care system with infected individuals as the inputs and recovered and deceased individuals as the outputs. Along with the information on the time spent in each state, this is an instrument for the budgeting of medical process, planning and scenario analysis (see, e.g., Alvarez et al. 2020 , Di Domenico et al. 2020 , Aguirregabiria et al. 2020 and Atkeson 2020 .

Let us now examine the durations of various states of medical treatment conditional on transitioning to another state. The analysis concerns the entire sampling period of 104 days. In order to (partly) eliminate the right-censoring/ truncation bias, the analysis concerns only complete sojourn times. For example, the distribution of a sojourn time in state ICU conditional on exit to state Intubation is estimated from individuals who have accomplished that transition.

Thus, the adjustment is carried out by examining the sojourn times conditional on the exit state. It simplifies the estimation at the expense of disregarding incomplete sojourn times and the decreasing numbers of individuals left at the end of the sample. This last effect is due to delays in reporting.

Online appendix B2 presents the summary statistics of the conditional sojourn time distributions (mean, variance, quantiles), which are evaluated from samples of different sizes, such as N = 215 for state H of Hospitalization

before state DE of Death or N = 6 for state H of Hospitalization before state V of Ventilation. figure 8 feature fat right tails with 32 days of maximum Intubation. Depending on the severity level, 25% of individuals spend more than 8.5 days in level v 1 , 16.5 days in level v 2 and 14.5 days in level v 3 (see online appendix B2, 6). We observe a similar pattern in the mean duration with 6.6 days in level v 1 , 11.8 days in level v 2 and 9.1 days in level v 3 . The decrease of the number of days between levels v 2 and v 3 reveals that a higher effort in medical care increases the probability of survival. The conditional sojourn time distributions are valid state by state and have to be used with caution for inference on joint transitions. It is unlikely that an individual transitioning through states of H, ICU and T has an expected time of medical care equal to the sum of average times in H, ICU and T. There may exist a complicated negative or positive dependence between the sojourn times in the successive states. A patient with a severe condition may stay for a short time in ICU and a long time in T. Such complicated dependencies are better captured by means of a duration dependent transitions model (see section 4) than by an analysis of the joint distribution of sojourn times. Nevertheless, the correlation between the duration in H before exit to ICU and the duration in ICU before exit to Intubation is −0.128, the correlation between duration in ICU before exit to Intubation and duration in Intubation before Death is −0.233. These negative correlations support the above discussion.

The summary statistics given in sections 3.1 and 3.2 can be interpreted as evidence in favour or against the homogeneous Markov chain assumption A2(a). In particular, the empirical transition matrix given in table 1 is the maximum likelihood estimator of matrix P in a homogeneous Markov chain. Under assumption A2(a), the medical care process remains stationary and all non-stationarities in the counts of deceased and recovered are induced by the non-stationarity in the counts of individuals in state D and their increase during the early phase of the pandemic. This implies that the medical staff does not change their practices regarding the patient's treatment during the pandemic.

There is evidence in support of the homogeneous Markov chain assumption, such as the decreasing patterns of some duration densities, which resemble geometric densities and the fact that some of the densities do not depend on the state of exit. As well, the mean sojourn time computed directly from the duration data is often close to the mean sojourn time computed from the elements of the transition matrix in table 1. Let us, for example, consider the state T of Intubation with p jj = 0.89 (see table 1 ). Under assumption A2(a), the sojourn time follows a geometric distribution with mean 1/(1-p jj ) = 9.0 days, which can be compared with the expected values reported in online appendix B2, 6.

However, the homogeneous Markov chain assumption seems inadequate for some other states. Moreover, the sojourn times of the same individual in various states may be correlated, as mentioned above. Therefore, the homogeneous Markov Chain assumption does not seem to hold, although it conveniently provides a simple framework for computing summary statistics that can serve as benchmarks for comparison (see section 4.3.1). The alternative assumptions to replace assumption A2(a) are those of time dependence and duration dependence, for example.

Let us first examine if the medical care process is non-stationary. This can be done graphically by comparing the daily estimated transition matricesP t . By definition, the estimated transition probabilitiesp jk in table 1 are weighted averages:p

with weights that depend on the conditioning state and are proportional to the number of individuals in that state on day t. Figure 9 shows the trajectories of daily transition probabilitiesp j;k;t for selected states over the sampling period. The series have to be considered with caution because the number of individuals in a given state at a given date can be small. Therefore, we focus on the transitions from H and T to D (black lines) and from H and T to DE (pink and blue lines, respectively) computed from larger subsamples. These series display upward trends, while the transitions from H to H and T to T (not reported) have downward trends by the unit mass restriction. Thus, the times spent in these states seem to decline. That can be due to a change in the treatment process or to a left-censoring effect. Indeed, the time of the diagnosis is not equal to the time of infection. If more tests were performed over time, infectious individuals could be detected earlier and then it would be easier to cure them of COVID-19. The distinction between these alternative explanations is out of the scope of this paper.

Another remark concerns the evolution of the number of deaths. It is increasing smoothly from state H, which suggests it is being controlled. The evolution of deaths from state T is influenced by the increasing pressure on the beds available for intubation. Likely, some patients who were supposed to move from H to T, remained and died in state H instead of moving to T, which contributed to the increase in transition probability from H to DE.

This section extends the benchmark model by introducing duration dependence (assumption A2(c)). First, we describe the specification of the transition matrix. Next, we provide the estimation results. These results are used for adjusting the count summary statistics for right truncation bias and for prediction making.

The (8 × 8) transition probability matrix P i,t has components p j,k,i,t . The rows sum up to 1. Each row represents the probabilities of exit from a state j to another state k. The transition probabilities are specified as (conditional) multinomial logit models (see McFadden 1984) . The transition probabilities can depend on the time already spent in a state, denoted by Dur it (D) for state D. They depend on the state and vary with both individuals and time.

For example, let us illustrate the transitions p j,k,i,t from state j = 1 of D for individual i at time t: a. p 1,1,i.t = (D → D) / 1 b. p 1;2;i:t ¼ ðD ! ERÞ / expðβ 1;1 þ β 1;2 Dur it ðDÞÞ c. p 1;3;i;t ¼ ðD ! HÞ / expðβ 1;3 þ β 1;4 Dur it ðDÞÞ d. p 1;4;i;t ¼ ðD ! ICUÞ / expðβ 1;5 þ β 1;6 Dur it ðDÞÞ e. p 1;5;i;t ¼ ðD ! VÞ / expðβ 1;7 þ β 1;8 Dur it ðDÞÞ f. p 1;6;i;t ¼ ðD ! TÞ / expðβ 1;9 þ β 1;10 Dur it ðDÞÞ g. p 1;7;i;t ¼ ðD ! RÞ / expðβ 1;11 þ β 1;12 Dur it ðDÞÞ h. p 1;8;i;t ¼ ðD ! DEÞ / expðβ 1;13 Þ,

where Dur i,t (D) denotes the duration (time) already spent in the current state D and the symbol / denotes "proportional to," with the proportionality coefficient such that the above transition probabilities sum up to 1.

Because the coefficients of a multinomial model are not identifiable, an identifying constraint is imposed: in each row, the probabilities of remaining in a given state are assumed p j,j,i.t / 1, j = 1, . . . , 8 or, equivalently, the associated coefficients β are set equal to 0. Moreover, matrix P i,t is specified according to the transition scheme given in section 2.4 and the probabilities of state transitions that do not occur are set equal to 0.

We mentioned earlier that state D comprises individuals of two types: D 1 prior to a potential medical care and D 2 returned from medical care. Therefore, the transition to a medical care state concerns individuals in D 1 and depends on time spent in state D = D 1 .
The model with duration dependence is estimated by the maximum likelihood for the entire province of Ontario.

The estimation results are presented in table 2, which contains the estimated coefficients and standard errors for each row of the transition matrix. In each cell of table 2, the first coefficient is the intercept and the second one is the duration sensitivity. Table 2 does not report the coefficients associated with the probabilities of remaining in a given state, which are set proportional to 1, for identification. The empty cells in table 2 correspond to the transitions of probability 0. In addition, large negative values of coefficients suggest a transition with probability zero, such as for example from state V to R, which is consistent with the results given in table 1. The standard errors provided in table 2 need to be interpreted with caution. The lack of statistical significance of a reported duration coefficient does not necessary imply the absence of duration dependence because the duration variable also appears in the denominator of a transition probability computed from these coefficients. The duration dependence is introduced for each state except the state of emergency room (ER) because a majority of individuals stay in ER for only one day.

The parameter values of a multinomial model do not have a direct interpretation. Hence the values of parameters reported in table 2 are not interpretable. Instead the probabilities and the ratios of transition probabilities are interpretable (in the two-state case, the odd ratios are interpretable).

Let us consider the state of intubation T. After one day spent in this state, the ratio of the transition to D (i.e., the way to recovery) and the transition to death DE are expðβ 6;1 þ β 6;2 À β 6;11 Þ:
After 10 days, this ratio is expðβ 6;1 þ 10β 6;2 À β 6;11 Þ:

Therefore, the ratio of these two ratios 10 days/1 day is expð9β 6;2 Þ ¼ expðÀ0:22 Â 9Þ < 1: Thus, when the time spent in intubation T increases, the chance to exit on the way to recovery diminishes, compared with the earlier days.

The probabilities of transitions conditional on the sojourn time (duration) in each state of 1 to 15 days are displayed in figures 10 to 14. The revealed patterns provide evidence indicating the duration dependence of conditional transition probabilities.

Each figure contains panels, displaying the probabilityp jj of remaining in a given state j and the probabilitiesp jk of transitioning to other states k as functions of sojourn time spent in state j. We find that, consistent with table 1, the probabilities of remaining in each state are the highest either at the beginning or at the end of the 15-day period. At each sojourn day in state j, one can evaluate: (i) the expected remaining duration in state j equal to 1=ð1 Àp jj Þ and (ii) the probability of transitioning to state k, conditional on quitting state j from the ratiop jk =ð1 Àp jj Þ.

For illustration, consider the example of Intubation, with transition probabilities displayed in figure 14 . On day one in state T, the expected remaining duration is 1/(1 − 0.6) = 2.5 days. On day 10 in state T, the expected remaining duration is 1/(1 − 0.8) = 5 days, i.e., the expected total stay is of 15 days. On day one in state T, the probability of dying, conditional on quitting T is 0.02/(1 − 0.6) = 0.05. On day 10 in state T, that probability is 0.029/(1 − 0.8) = 0.15. We uncover the "mover-stayer" phenomenon, where the less vulnerable patients (movers) exit first, leaving the most vulnerable patients (stayers) with a higher probability of dying. Figure 10 depicts the dynamics of transition probabilities from state D, which need to be interpreted with caution because of poor quality of data on transitions from this category. For example, state R of Recovery is observed only at the end of the sample, and many individuals are reported as remaining in state D in the data set while they may have recovered earlier. Therefore the transition from state D to state R of Recovery, computed from the estimated parameters is necessarily underestimated. Nevertheless, the data set includes reliable information on the transition to/from the medical states and the state DE of death. Thus, the estimates can be used to accurately evaluate the dynamic of probabilities and counts in these states.

The duration dependence patterns of transition probabilities from D are close to linear, while the patterns observed in transition probabilities from other states are mostly non-linear. These can have monotonic convex or concave patterns, including a hump shaped pattern. This is due to the nonlinear logit specification of probabilities. Figure 10 shows that the probability that an individual in state D stays in state D is greater than 0.93 and increases with the duration of state D. The probability of recovering varies between 0.060/(1 − 0.93) = 0.85 after one day and 0.045/(1 − 0.95) = 0.9 after 15 days. The next most likely transitions from state D are to state H of Hospitalization and to state DE of Death. Figure 11 displays the transitions from state H of Hospitalization. After one day of Hospitalization, the probability of remaining hospitalized is 0.5 and the expected duration is two days. These quantities increase quickly after 15 days, while the probability of returning to state D, conditional on quitting state H decreases to 0 after 15 days. The next most likely transitions from H are either to ICU or T with almost equal probabilities, which are decreasing functions of time. A transition to state DE of Death is also likely to occur, with a probability increasing over time. Figure 12 shows the transition probabilities from ICU. The most likely transitions away from ICU are to states D and H with close and decreasing probabilities, followed by Intubation T and death DE. The remaining probabilities are negligible, given the reported number of individuals in ICU. The transitions from state V of Ventilation displayed in figure 13 are most likely towards states D and ICU, both with probabilities decreasing gradually over time, followed by the transition to Intubation T, with a probability falling sharply to 0 after two days. Otherwise, we observe transitions to state H with a probability decreasing over time or to state DE of Death with a probability increasing over time. The transition probability to state R is negligible.

The transitions from state T of Intubation are shown in figure 14 . The most likely transitions are to state D, with a probability decreasing over time or to state DE of Death with a probability increasing over time. There is also a nonzero probability of transitioning back to state H, which decreases over time, while the probabilities of transition to the remaining states are negligible.

In general, the probabilities of transition to Death after long durations are close to the transition probabilities in table 1, computed under the homogeneous Markov chain assumption. The results concerning the probability to recover are affected by the lack of the date of recovery and need to be interpreted with caution.

So far, our study concerned all 34 diagnosis health unit areas. Let us now compare the transition probabilities with duration dependence between two regions with large numbers of COVID-19 cases: Toronto with 5,928 cases and the rest of the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), i.e., the municipal regions of Durham, Halton, Peel and York, where the numbers of diagnosed cases were 1,087, 497, 2,628 and 1,694, respectively. Tables 3 and 4 show the transition matrices estimated from the subsamples of patients diagnosed in Toronto and the rest of the GTA. Tables B1 and B2 in online appendix B3 show the estimated parameter values and standard errors for the transition models with duration dependence estimated for Toronto and the rest of the GTA. Although the parameter values themselves are not interpretable, the large negative coefficient values suggest that some transitions are unlikely to occur in either area considered. For instance, the transition from state ER to R and DE are unlikely to occur both in Toronto and the rest of the GTA. Figures A1 to A5 illustrate the duration dependence in transition probabilities estimated for the two areas considered. 2 We observe the presence of duration dependence with mostly non-linear patterns, similar to those reported for the entire province. The duration-dependent conditional probabilities in Toronto and the rest of the GTA are similar too and often differ only in terms of their levels. The main findings are as follows.
body_text.section: Toronto and other health units in the Greater Toronto Area

body_text.text: (a) The data reveal the outcomes of the crisis in the long-term care facilities, when high mortality rates were recorded at the beginning of the outbreak in retirement homes mostly located outside the city of Toronto. 3 As shown in tables 3 and 4 and figure A1 , the probability of dying while in state D is higher in the rest of the GTA than in Toronto. We also observe that the transitions from state D to hospitalization occur with a higher probability in Toronto than in the rest of the GTA and the whole province. In Toronto, the 2 Only non-negligible transition probabilities conditional on duration dependence are reported.
body_text.section: Toronto and other health units in the Greater Toronto Area

body_text.text: 3 Such as Markhaven, for example. probability of moving from state D to H conditional on quitting state D after day one is about 0.113 and decreases over sojourn time, while in the rest of the GTA, it is only 0.031 after day one. This implies that individuals diagnosed with COVID-19 are more likely to be hospitalized if they live in Toronto. At the same time, we observe a higher likelihood of death among patients hospitalized in Toronto, compared with the rest of the GTA. After day one, this probability is 0.053 and increases to 0.40 after day 15 (figure A2). In the rest of the GTA, the probability of transition from H to DE conditional on quitting hospitalization increases from 0.017 on day one to 0.3 on day 15.
body_text.section: Toronto and other health units in the Greater Toronto Area

body_text.text: (b) There is evidence suggesting differences in medical practice between the two areas. In Toronto, patients are more likely to receive more intense care sooner and the intensity of medical care keeps increasing at a faster pace until the death or recovery. This could be because of a higher rate of beds equipped for tracheal intubation procedures in Toronto (see Gourieroux et al. 2021 for endogenous patient assignments). More specifically, in Toronto, a patient spends on average one day less under ventilation and moves sooner to state T of Intubation, compared with the rest of the GTA (tables 3 and 4). Moreover, in Toronto, patients are more likely to die in states T of Intubation than in the rest of the GTA (figure A5), where patients die more frequently from states ICU and V of Ventilation. The probability of dying while in state T increases over sojourn time and is higher in Toronto on each day, compared with the rest of the GTA (figure A5). Figure A5 also suggests that in the rest of the GTA patients are more likely to be moved from state T to states ICU and V. The probability of dying while in state ICU is higher in the rest of the GTA than in Toronto, as illustrated in figure A5 . More specifically, in Toronto the probability of transition from ICU to DE, conditional on quitting ICU, is 0.02 after day one and increases to 0.34 after day 15, while it is 0.04 after day one and increases to 0.64 after day 15 in the rest of the GTA.
body_text.section: Toronto and other health units in the Greater Toronto Area

body_text.text: Also, in Toronto, the transition from state H to ICU has a higher probability than in the rest of the GTA. In Toronto, patients are upgraded to state ICU with a probability of 0.05 conditional on quitting H after day one, which decreases over sojourn time. In the rest of the GTA, that probability is equal to only 0.003 after day one and increases to 0.04 after day 15 ( figure A2 ).
body_text.section: Toronto and other health units in the Greater Toronto Area

body_text.text: (c) The empirical results concerning the differences between Toronto and the rest of the GTA can be affected by errors in reporting and/or different data collecting and reporting practices under the iPHIS and CORES systems. In particular, the data on transitions to state V in Toronto seem inaccurate. More specifically, in table 3, we find 0 probabilities of transitions to state V except from states D and T, while in the rest of the GTA and the whole province the probabilities of transitions to state V from other states of medical care are different from 0 (tables 2 and 4). For example, figure A2 implies that transitions from state H to V, which are not reported in Toronto, occur in the rest of the GTA with probability 0.03 conditional on quitting state H, which decreases to 0 over five sojourn days. This may be due to discrepancies in the reporting practices across the areas considered.
body_text.section: Toronto and other health units in the Greater Toronto Area

body_text.text: Depending on the number of diagnosed patients, the knowledge of transition probabilities and expected sojourn times of patients in various states of medical treatment can be used to predict the hospital resources needed for each type of treatment. This information is essential for the strategic planning and budgeting at the level of hospitals and funding from the Ontario Government in the fight against COVID-19 and preparation for future outbreaks of infectious diseases.

Let us now explain how the transition model estimated from the entire sample can be used to compute the fitted values of counts over the observation period and the forecasts. First, we consider the computation under the homogeneous Markov chain assumption and next under the assumption of duration dependence. We focus on the counts of patients who are hospitalized (state H), in ICU and state T of Intubation.

Recall that state D includes two types of histories: D 1 are individuals who are isolated at the detection date and D 2 are individuals who are on their way to recovery after a transition through H, ICU, V and T. For subsequent computation, we need to separate these two types of observations and focus on D 1 . The first row of the transition matrix in table 1 is replaced by the row in table 5.

The modified transition matrix is denoted byP. After being diagnosed, an individual is assigned to a state. The time-independent (constant) probabilities of assignments estimated from the entire sample are given in table 6. We have a causal scheme with three episodes:
1. the detection episode that ends at the case reported date, 2. the assignment episode, with the selection based on v given in table, and 3. the medical care process summarized by matrixP.
At time T = May 5, 2020, we observe for each individual a recovery, a death or a censored duration in the last state, such as one of the medical care states.

The fitted values, i.e., the expected counts, are computed from the sequence X t of counts of new diagnosed on day t (see figure 2 ). Let N t denote the row vector of length 8, with elements equal to the counts of individuals in each state on day t. The fitted counts are given by

where X τ denotes the counts of new diagnosed and v is the vector of assignments in table 6. Thus, we evaluate the future expected counts for each cohort (generation) τ and sum over the past cohorts. Figure Indeed, the fitted values provide an adjustment for the right truncation bias revealed in figure 3 . It is therefore important to use the model-based figures instead of data-based figures in the presence of truncation and reporting lag problems, to avoid misleading conclusions, especially concerning the peak of the pandemic. Figure 15 shows the peak of state H of hospitalization that seems about to appear at the beginning of May for state H (from recent data, we know that there was a peak in the first wave, followed by another peak later on). The peak in state T of Intubation is not visible from the fitted counts because of long sojourn times in state T.
A similar analysis can be performed by using the transition model with duration dependence discussed in sections 4.1 and 4.2. Then, equation (4.1) becomes

where X τ denotes the counts of newly diagnosed and v is the vector of assignments in table 6. Equation (4.2) accounts for the fact that the matrices depend on time through the durations spent in each state. Because the individual durations Dur it are random, the product of matrices has to be integrated out, which can be easily done by simulations. Figures B1 and B2 in online appendix B3 show the fitted and observed counts of patients under medical care and the cumulative counts of deaths, respectively. Figure B1 documents the good fit of the duration dependent transition model to the data and the satisfactory predictive power of the model. The model predicts, as expected from figure 3, higher than recorded medical state counts over the last part of the sampling period until May 5. Online appendix figure B2 plots the fitted and the observed number of cumulative deaths. The figure shows that the total cumulative death count is accurately predicted. The figures confirm that the model provides an adjustment for right truncation and reporting lag. As mentioned earlier, the data suffer from a right truncation bias and a lag in reporting that start around day 80 (April 11) of the observational period and generate decreasing patterns of daily counts, found ex post incompatible with the publicly available counts provided later by the PHO. The model is shown to "adjust" for these biases.

A similar approach can be applied to predict the future counts and numbers of beds required for the different types of medical care (see Grasselli et al. 2020 and Murray 2020 for predictions of beds in Italy and the US, respectively).

Because of the time of medical treatment, we recommend predicting a term structure of counts, up to say 20 days rather than computing one day ahead forecasts only. This long-run prediction requires additional forecasting of future counts of new diagnosed X T+1 , X T+1 , . . ., X T+H . This is possible only if the model is completed by a dynamic model for the X t 's, from a SI component of the SIRD-type model, obtained by logit adjustments for the series of cumulated counts of diagnosed individuals (Berkson 1944) . This is clearly out of the scope of the present paper.

The empirical results obtained in this paper lead to a number of recommendations for the policy-makers in Ontario. These recommendations, listed below, concern: (i) the surveillance of medical practice across the province, (ii) the quality of data collection and dissemination and (iiii) the modelling and forecasting of COVID-19 infections.
(i) Our study reveals plausible differences in death rates of patients under treatment for COVID-19 between Toronto and the rest of the GTA.

A surveillance of medical care should be implemented to identify the most successful procedures and disseminate that information across the province. (ii) The strategic plans for the fight against COVID-19 and future outbreaks of infectious diseases should provide guidelines on data reporting for health information systems, such as the iPHIS and CORES.

Medical history records need to be consistent across the health units to avoid, for example, ambiguous interpretation of differences between patient flows in hospitals, unless such differences really exist. The definition of states of reference, such as Recovered, need to be coherent and time invariant. Common standards should be imposed regarding the missing values, to reduce the number of variables with overwhelmingly incomplete records. A higher accuracy of records would improve the quality and reliability of publicly disseminated aggregate data at www.publichealthontario.ca. We recommend reporting not only the aggregate counts but also the transition rates between various states, like those computed and examined in this paper. As we have documented, the transition statistics contain more valuable information about the dynamics of the epidemics and the efficiency of the health care system than the cross-sectional counts. (iii) The models used for projections of COVID-19 infections in Ontario should be publicly disclosed along with the estimated or calibrated parameter values and fixed inputs, such as the unobserved rate of asymptomatic individuals used in the calculations. For Bayesian forecasting methods, a description and rationale for priors should be provided. This would enhance the transparency of the projections and enable further research and feedback from the academic community.

We also recommend the use of the state transition model with duration dependence proposed in this paper and its extensions including the patient characteristics and explanatory variables, for the modelling and forecasting of counts in various states and resource allocation to public health units across the province.

This paper examined the process of medical treatment during the early phase of COVID-19 pandemic in Ontario. We investigated the medical care dynamics and its adjustment over time. We considered a benchmark transition model based on the homogeneous Markov chain assumption and examined its extension involving duration dependence. The duration dependence revealed in state transitions points to an important limitation of the epidemiological SIR-type models. An additional advantage of the transition model is that it provides a truncation adjustment that helps eliminate misleading results based on a naive interpretation of the series of aggregate counts.

Our analysis was carried out under a simplifying assumption that the detection process of infected individuals can be disregarded. However, the detection process may induce both left truncation and left censoring. The analysis of left truncation in the case of COVID-19, is complicated by the large number of asymptomatic individuals who are difficult to detect (see, e.g., Gourieroux and Jasiak 2020 for an approach to recovering the unobserved counts of undetected infectious individuals). The left censoring arises in COVID-19 because the detection date does not coincide with the infection date, and the difference between these dates may depend on the detection efforts and the numbers of tests performed.

The transition model with duration dependence has been applied to individual data on COVID-19 infections in Ontario and in Toronto and the rest of the GTA. The forecasts of future counts provided by the model have been proven satisfactory and accurate projections were obtained for the counts of deceased. The transition model-based analysis can be extended further to accommodate individual characteristics and spatial dependence between the infections in Ontario.
Supplementary material accompanies the online version of this article.

The histograms illustrate only the sample distributions evaluated from a sufficiently large number of observations. Durations of state diagnosed (D) prior to transition NOTES: ER = emergency room. ICU = intensive care unit. Durations of state hospitalization prior to transition The histograms show decreasing patterns suggesting geometric conditional distributions of sojourn times, except for state T of Intubation, illustrated in three panels of figure 8. The exit state is unknown at the entry time into state T of Intubation. It can be considered as an indicator of severity of the disease affecting the length of required Intubation. Under the assumption of perfect foresight of future severity, we distinguish three severity levels for the intubated individuals: v 1 = D, v 2 = ICU, v 3 = DE. Case reported on March 29, in the emergency room (ER) on March 26, returned and hospitalized on April 3, in the ICU and under ventilation from April 6 until April 23, not recovered by May 5. 3. Case reported on April 16, hospitalized on April 24, not recovered until May 5.

For example, an individual cannot go back to state ICU after recovery, etc.
